given.text:
My main collaboration with Jean-Louis was on the creation a C++ library of risk models at Fortis Bank. An aspect of the project that was both challenging and delightful is that the boundary between the roles of business (my team) and IT (Jean-Louis's team) was highly blurred, with both teams contributing heavily in terms of design, implementation, and ideas. One of Jean-Louis's responsibilities in the project was to ensure that the library code would remain production-level quality (as required for the production of official risk figures), in spite of a significant part of it being contributed by people with no prior background in C++ or structured development methodologies. Jean-Louis was the right person to take this charge, thanks to his deep knowledge in the field, his passion for sharing it, and his talent for making highly technical matters accessible to laypeople, all this combined with an acute ability to think out of the box. Priorities and projects changed with the merger, but I later had many other opportunities of appreciating, through both professional advices and friendly conversations, Jean-Louis's insightful and opinionated (though never dogmatic) views on various programming topics, as well as on general scientific matters.

Jean-Louis worked with us on several web/e-business projects including a dedicated web-based CRM, acting as database architect, application layer & persistence layer programmer. He delivered an outstanding job in these areas. Furthermore he's a great team driver showing the ability to think out of the box. Definitely a most valuable professionnal.

Jean-Louis started working for Fortis Bank in 2007. Until 2010, he was involved as technical expert in a development of an internal risk project by using C and C++. One of his main achievements during that period was the setup of the grid computing (platform symphony). The first six months 2011, he was involved in the migration of a reporting tool wrote in Borland C++ that we received from the business. Technology used for that was: C# / WPF / MS SQL Server. Next, from mid-2011 until now, he helped us to setup the new development framework and started by making bug fixes and small development in the new Risk Application. He was also a key element by teaching the team and giving us his expertise in C# / WPF / MVVM / Test Driven development. By all these work experiences, he showed he was a real team player with a good communication skills and a great commitment to the deadline requirement of the projects.

Jean-Louis is an efficient Software Engineer. He is always open for discussion and has a real talent to transmit his enthusiasm over new technologies and methodologies. He is also a team driver an provide efficient solutions.

I worked with Jean-Louis on the information management project at the Belgian Federal Department of Justice. He delivered a huge component of our cross-platform C++ framework, the object-relational mapping and persistence layer. Furthermore he acted as our C++ guru and collective conscience as it came to the most optimal way to implement solutions and evolve the framework. Most of all Jean-Louis was a very dependable team-player.

My team was responsible for validating pricing models for which task we developed a pricing library in C++. Later, this library was used also in production for daily risk measurements. Jean-Louis was helping us to maintain this library. He made a vast contribution to the library by redesigning it, optimising it and doing all the low-level programming. Besides that he is a C++ and Perl guru, he had no difficulty with designing and implementing financial tools and models either. He led and participated in several large-scale projects. He was always committed, professional and keen to help and guide his colleagues.
